analysisSummary.summaryText: Analysis Complete — 8 key issues found. ⚠️  Found 8 illegal clause(s) that violate Massachusetts law | ⚡ Identified 10 risky term(s) that could be problematic | ✓ Found 6 tenant-favorable provision(s) | Power Imbalance Score: 100/100 (Concerning)

highlights.category: Chapter 186, Section 15E
highlights.text: The [NAME_REDACTED]ses are delivered to [NAME_REDACTED] and [NAME_REDACTED] accepts the [NAME_REDACTED]ses in their present condition, “AS IS,” it being agreed that [NAME_REDACTED] has had a n opportunity to examine and inspect the [NAME_REDACTED]ses in all respects, that [NAME_REDACTED]dlord has made no representations or warranties of any kind with respect thereto, and that [NAME_REDACTED]dlord shall have no obligation to do any work on, or make any improvements to the [NAME_REDACTED] ses or the condition thereof.
highlights.explanation: This clause attempts to waive the landlord's responsibility for defects, potentially including violations of the building code, existing at the time of letting, which is prohibited by M.G.L. c. 186, § 15E. Specifically, Section 15E states that an owner cannot raise as a defense in an action brought by a tenant for an injury caused by a defect in a common area, that the defect existed at the time of the letting, if that defect is a building code violation at the time of the injury. The waiver of this provision is void and unenforceable.

highlights.category: Chapter 186, Section 15
highlights.text: 9.2. Release.  To the maximum extent this [NAME_REDACTED]se may be made effective according to law, [NAME_REDACTED] agrees to use and occupy the [NAME_REDACTED]s es at [NAME_REDACTED]'s own risk, and [NAME_REDACTED]dlord shall have no responsibility or liability for any loss or damage to fixtures or other personal property of [NAME_REDACTED] or any person claiming by, through or under [NAME_REDACTED].  Without limitation, [NAME_REDACTED] agrees that [NAME_REDACTED]dlord sha ll not be responsible or liable to [NAME_REDACTED], or those claiming by, through or under [NAME_REDACTED], for any loss or damage resulting to [NAME_REDACTED] or those claiming by, through or under [NAME_REDACTED], its or their property from the breaking, bursting, stopping or leaking of [ORG_REDACTED] and wires, and water, gas or steam pipes.
highlights.explanation: This clause attempts to exculpate the landlord from liability for damage to the tenant's property, which is prohibited by M.G.L. c. 186, § 15.  Specifically, the landlord cannot contractually eliminate liability for damages caused by defects in the property, including those relating to utilities such as water, gas, and electricity. This clause is an illegal attempt to shift the responsibility for property damage to the tenant, even if the damage is due to the landlord's negligence or failure to maintain the property.

highlights.category: Chapter 186, Section 15
highlights.text:
9.1. Indemnification.  [NAME_REDACTED] shall, during the term hereof, assume and maintain exclusive control of 
the [NAME_REDACTED]ses and defend, indemn ify and save harmless [NAME_REDACTED]dlord from and against all claims, expenses 
or liability of whatever nature arising from any act, omission or negligence of [NAME_REDACTED], [NAME_REDACTED]'s 
contractors, agents, employees, customers, and invitees, or anyone claiming by, through or  under 
[NAME_REDACTED], or arising, directly or indirectly, from any accident, injury or damage whatsoever, however 
caused, to any person, or to the property of any person, occurring after [NAME_REDACTED] enters the [NAME_REDACTED]ses for 
any reason and until the end of the term of t his [NAME_REDACTED]se and, thereafter, so long as [NAME_REDACTED] or any occupant 
claiming under [NAME_REDACTED] is in occupancy of any part of the [NAME_REDACTED]ses, in or about the [NAME_REDACTED]ses, or arising 
from any accident occurring outside the [NAME_REDACTED]ses but within the general area of the [NAME_REDACTED]se s, where 
such accident, injury or damage results or is claimed to have resulted from any act, omission or 
negligence on the part of [NAME_REDACTED] or [NAME_REDACTED]'s contractors, agents, employees, customers, and invitees, or 
anyone claiming by, through or under [NAME_REDACTED].
highlights.explanation: This clause requires the tenant to indemnify the landlord for claims arising from *any* act, omission, or negligence, regardless of whether it's the tenant's fault or the landlord's fault. This is an illegal indemnification clause under Massachusetts law which prohibits landlords from requiring tenants to indemnify them from the landlord's own negligence.

highlights.category: Chapter 186, Section 15
highlights.text:
9.2. Release.  To the maximum extent this [NAME_REDACTED]se may be made effective according to law, [NAME_REDACTED] 
agrees to use and occupy the [NAME_REDACTED]s es at [NAME_REDACTED]'s own risk, and [NAME_REDACTED]dlord shall have no responsibility or 
liability for any loss or damage to fixtures or other personal property of [NAME_REDACTED] or any person claiming 
by, through or under [NAME_REDACTED].  Without limitation, [NAME_REDACTED] agrees that [NAME_REDACTED]dlord sha ll not be responsible 
or liable to [NAME_REDACTED], or those claiming by, through or under [NAME_REDACTED], for any loss or damage resulting to 
[NAME_REDACTED] or those claiming by, through or under [NAME_REDACTED], its or their property from the breaking, bursting, 
stopping or leaking of [ORG_REDACTED] and wires, and water, gas or steam pipes.
highlights.explanation: This clause attempts to release the landlord from liability for any loss or damage to the tenant's property, even if caused by the landlord's negligence (e.g., leaking pipes due to poor maintenance). This is an illegal exculpatory clause under Massachusetts law.

highlights.category: Chapter 186, Section 15
highlights.text:
10.3.  [ORG_REDACTED].  [NAME_REDACTED]dlord shall be named as an additional insured on all 
insurance policies.  All required insurance shall be written with such companies qualified to do business 
in Massachusetts, as [NAME_REDACTED] shall select and [NAME_REDACTED]dlord shall approve, which  approval [NAME_REDACTED]dlord agrees not 
to withhold unreasonably. Without limiting [NAME_REDACTED]dlord's other rights under any other provisions of this 
[NAME_REDACTED]se, if [NAME_REDACTED] shall fail to keep the [NAME_REDACTED]ses insured as provided herein, and if such failure shall 
continue to a period of ten (10) days following written notice by [NAME_REDACTED]dlord to [NAME_REDACTED] thereof, then 
[NAME_REDACTED]dlord, without further notice to [NAME_REDACTED], may take out and pay for such insurance, and the amount of 
such payment shall become due and payable as [ORG_REDACTED] on demand. [NAME_REDACTED] hereby waives any and all rights of recovery which it might otherwise have against 
[NAME_REDACTED]dlord, its agents, employees and other persons for whom [NAME_REDACTED]dlord may be responsible for any loss 
or damage to [NAME_REDACTED] property or improvements in the [NAME_REDACTED]ses whi ch are either required to be 
insured under the terms of this [NAME_REDACTED]se or which [NAME_REDACTED], in the absence of any such requirement, elects to 
insure, notwithstanding that the loss or damage may result from the negligence, willful act or default 
under the terms of this [NAME_REDACTED]se by [NAME_REDACTED]dlord, its agents, employees, contractors, or other persons for 
whom [NAME_REDACTED]dlord may be responsible.
highlights.explanation: This clause contains a waiver of subrogation and release from liability for the landlord's negligence, which is illegal. The tenant is waiving the right to recover from the landlord even if the landlord is negligent.

highlights.category: Chapter 186, Section 15
highlights.text:
(c) If any part of the [NAME_REDACTED]ses is damaged by fire or other casualty or is taken by a public 
authority and this [NAME_REDACTED]se is not terminated by [NAME_REDACTED]dlord or [NAME_REDACTED] as provided above, [NAME_REDACTED] shall 
proceed with reasonable diligence to repair and restore the [NAME_REDACTED]ses, or what remains thereof in the 
case of a partial taking, to its condition prior to such t aking.  [NAME_REDACTED] acknowledges and agrees that in no 
event shall [NAME_REDACTED]dlord be liable for any injury, harm or any other loss, cost, expense, demand, claim, or 
have any obligation to repair, replace, improve, restore and/or rebuild, any damage of any kind or 
nature whatsoever to the [NAME_REDACTED]ses or any portion thereof caused by an eminent domain taking or by 
fire, flood or other casualty.
highlights.explanation: This clause attempts to release the landlord from the obligation to repair the premises in the event of fire, flood or casualty. While landlords can allocate responsibilities in a lease, they cannot exculpate themselves from liability for damages caused by their own negligence. If the damage is a result of the landlord's negligence or failure to maintain the property, this clause is likely unenforceable.

highlights.category: Chapter 186, Section 15
highlights.text:
[NAME_REDACTED] hereby waives any and all rights of recovery which it might otherwise have against 
[NAME_REDACTED]dlord, its agents, employees and other persons for whom [NAME_REDACTED]dlord may be responsible for any loss 
or damage to [NAME_REDACTED] property or improvements in the [NAME_REDACTED]ses whi ch are either required to be 
insured under the terms of this [NAME_REDACTED]se or which [NAME_REDACTED], in the absence of any such requirement, elects to 
insure, notwithstanding that the loss or damage may result from the negligence, willful act or default 
under the terms of this [NAME_REDACTED]se by [NAME_REDACTED]dlord, its agents, employees, contractors, or other persons for 
whom [NAME_REDACTED]dlord may be responsible.
highlights.explanation: This clause attempts to indemnify the landlord and preclude them from liability for their own negligence, willful acts, or defaults, which is prohibited by Massachusetts law. It is an exculpatory clause that shifts the burden of the landlord's negligence onto the tenant, and attempts to waive rights.

highlights.category: Chapter 186, Section 15
highlights.text:
[NAME_REDACTED] acknowledges and agrees that in no 
event shall [NAME_REDACTED]dlord be liable for any injury, harm or any other loss, cost, expense, demand, claim, or 
have any obligation to repair, replace, improve, restore and/or rebuild, any damage of any kind or 
nature whatsoever to the [NAME_REDACTED]ses or any portion thereof caused by an eminent domain taking or by 
fire, flood or other casualty.
highlights.explanation: This clause attempts to absolve the landlord from liability or responsibility for repairs due to eminent domain, fire, flood, or other casualties. This is an attempt to limit liability for the landlord's obligations. This could violate Chapter 186 Section 15 depending on the specific interpretation of 'misconduct of the lessor or landlord'. It would likely be unenforceable if the damage or injury was the result of the landlord's negligence.

highlights.category: Potentially excessive interest on late rent payments and conflicts with M.G.L. c. 186, §15B(1)(c).
highlights.text: 4.5. Interest. All payments becoming due under this [NAME_REDACTED]se and not paid when due s hall bear interest from the applicable due date until received by [NAME_REDACTED]dlord at an annual rate equal to the prime rate of interest charged from time to time by [ORG_REDACTED] or its successor, plus two percent (2%).
highlights.explanation: M.G.L. c. 186, §15B(1)(c) states that no lease or other rental agreement shall impose any interest or penalty for failure to pay rent until thirty days after such rent shall have been due. This clause imposes interest immediately upon a late payment, which could be considered a penalty imposed before the 30-day grace period. The specific interest rate also needs to be checked to ensure it doesn't violate usury laws.

highlights.category: Unclear division of responsibility and potential for shifting landlord's repair obligations onto the tenant.
highlights.text: 6.1. [NAME_REDACTED] Responsibility.  [NAME_REDACTED] shall be responsible for maintaining the [NAME_REDACTED]ses in g ood and clean condition and order at its sole expense.  Without limiting the foregoing, [NAME_REDACTED] shall keep the [NAME_REDACTED]ses, including, without limitation, the electrical fixtures, windows, halls, stairwells, lavatories and all other areas of the Building, the landscaping (including, without limitation, keeping the grass neat and cut and trimming of trees and bushes) in good condition, damage by fire or other casualty, and ordinary wear and tear only excepted.
highlights.explanation: While it's common for commercial leases to have tenants responsible for maintenance, this clause is overly broad. It assigns responsibility for 'all other areas of the Building,' which might include areas typically maintained by the landlord. It needs to be clearly defined which areas are solely for the tenant's use and which are common areas, and the tenant's responsibility should be limited to the leased premises and not extend to structural elements or common areas. The landlord is generally responsible for maintaining the structural integrity of the building and common areas. The clause also requires the tenant to maintain electrical fixtures, which can be problematic if those fixtures require specialized skills to repair.

highlights.category: Shifting maintenance responsibilities to the tenant is unusual and possibly illegal depending on the exact nature of the required maintenance. Landlords typically have the statutory responsibility for maintaining the premises in habitable condition (implied warranty of habitability).
highlights.text:
6.4 [NAME_REDACTED] Failure to Maintain.  If any maintenance, repair and/or replacements is required to be 
made by [NAME_REDACTED] pursuant to the terms hereof and [NAME_REDACTED] fails to cure the same within thirty (30) days 
after no tice by [NAME_REDACTED]dlord (or, in the event of an emergency, with such notice as is practicable), [NAME_REDACTED]dlord 
shall have the right (but shall not be obligated) to make such repairs, replacements or perform 
maintenance work or any other work required of [NAME_REDACTED] pursuant  to this [NAME_REDACTED]se and charge the cost 
thereof to [NAME_REDACTED] as [ORG_REDACTED], which, if not paid within thirty (30) days from the presentment of 
invoices therefore, shall bear interest at the rate set forth herein.
highlights.explanation: While commercial leases may allow for shifting some repair responsibilities to the tenant, residential leases have significant limitations. The phrase 'any other work required of [NAME_REDACTED] pursuant to this [NAME_REDACTED]se' is overly broad. This clause is ambiguous as to the type of maintenance being shifted to the tenant. If it includes items related to habitability, it could be deemed an illegal waiver of the landlord's duty to maintain a safe and habitable premises. It also isn't clear if the Landlord's notice has to be in writing, which could cause issues with proof. Charging the tenant interest for unpaid repair costs adds to the risk, as it is uncommon and could be seen as a penalty.

highlights.category: The landlord has broad discretion to deny assignment or subletting. Although permissible in commercial leases, this may be problematic if unreasonably applied and found to violate the implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing.
highlights.text:
8.5 Assignment and Subleasing.  [NAME_REDACTED] shall not assign, sublet, underlet, mortgage, pledge or 
encumber (collectively referred to as "[NAME_REDACTED]") this [NAME_REDACTED]se without [NAME_REDACTED]dlord's prior written consent, 
which may be withheld in [NAME_REDACTED]dlord’s sole discretion.
highlights.explanation: While landlords generally have the right to approve or disapprove of potential assignees or sublessees, the 'sole discretion' clause gives the landlord unfettered power. While this may be acceptable in a commercial lease, a court may find that an arbitrary and unreasonable refusal to allow assignment or subletting violates the implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing, especially if the lease is for a long term and the tenant's circumstances change. The tenant may argue that the landlord is unreasonably preventing them from mitigating their damages should they need to move out before the lease term expires.

highlights.category: The scope of indemnification is extremely broad and could potentially require the tenant to indemnify the landlord even for the landlord's own negligence.
highlights.text:
9.1. Indemnification.  [NAME_REDACTED] shall, during the term hereof, assume and maintain exclusive control of 
the [NAME_REDACTED]ses and defend, indemn ify and save harmless [NAME_REDACTED]dlord from and against all claims, expenses 
or liability of whatever nature arising from any act, omission or negligence of [NAME_REDACTED], [NAME_REDACTED]'s 
contractors, agents, employees, customers, and invitees, or anyone claiming by, through or  under 
[NAME_REDACTED], or arising, directly or indirectly, from any accident, injury or damage whatsoever, however 
caused, to any person, or to the property of any person, occurring after [NAME_REDACTED] enters the [NAME_REDACTED]ses for 
any reason and until the end of the term of t his [NAME_REDACTED]se and, thereafter, so long as [NAME_REDACTED] or any occupant 
claiming under [NAME_REDACTED] is in occupancy of any part of the [NAME_REDACTED]ses, in or about the [NAME_REDACTED]ses, or arising 
from any accident occurring outside the [NAME_REDACTED]ses but within the general area of the [NAME_REDACTED]se s, where 
such accident, injury or damage results or is claimed to have resulted from any act, omission or 
negligence on the part of [NAME_REDACTED] or [NAME_REDACTED]'s contractors, agents, employees, customers, and invitees, or 
anyone claiming by, through or under [NAME_REDACTED].
highlights.explanation: While indemnification clauses are common, this clause is very broad and potentially problematic. It requires the tenant to indemnify the landlord against *all* claims arising from *any* act, omission or negligence of the tenant or anyone related to the tenant, even if the landlord is also negligent. Massachusetts courts disfavor indemnification clauses that require a party to indemnify another for its own negligence, unless the clause is clear and unequivocal. This clause may not meet that standard, and a court could find it unenforceable if the landlord is partially at fault for the underlying claim.

highlights.category: The entire article deals with indemnification and release, which are areas prone to landlord overreach and potential violations of tenant rights.
highlights.text: ARTICLE IX:  INDEMNIFICATION; RELEASE
highlights.explanation: The title itself signals that this article contains provisions requiring the tenant to give up rights or assume liabilities.

highlights.category: Requiring the tenant to maintain insurance even after the lease term ends could be problematic.
highlights.text:
10.1  [NAME_REDACTED] Insurance.  [NAME_REDACTED] shall obtain and keep in force at its own expense so long as this 
[NAME_REDACTED]se remains in effect and thereafter so long as [NAME_REDACTED], or anyone claiming by, through or under 
[NAME_REDACTED], uses or occupies the [NAME_REDACTED]ses or any part thereof, policies of insurance for the benefit of such 
parties, in the amounts, and in the manner and form se t forth in this Section; provided, however, that 
amounts of insurance coverage may from time to time be increased.
highlights.explanation: The clause is vague about when and why insurance is needed 'thereafter'. It could be interpreted as requiring the tenant to maintain insurance indefinitely, which is unreasonable.

highlights.category: While seemingly reasonable on the surface, requiring the landlord's approval of the tenant's insurance company opens the door for potential abuse.
highlights.text:
10.3.  [ORG_REDACTED].  [NAME_REDACTED]dlord shall be named as an additional insured on all 
insurance policies.  All required insurance shall be written with such companies qualified to do business 
in Massachusetts, as [NAME_REDACTED] shall select and [NAME_REDACTED]dlord shall approve, which  approval [NAME_REDACTED]dlord agrees not 
to withhold unreasonably.
highlights.explanation: The landlord could unreasonably withhold approval and force the tenant to use a more expensive or less favorable insurance company.

highlights.category: This clause assigns all rights to compensation from eminent domain to the landlord. While landlords are typically entitled to compensation for the value of the property, tenants are also usually entitled to compensation for the loss of their business, leasehold improvements, and relocation costs.
highlights.text:
(d) In the event of a taking by eminent domain, [NAME_REDACTED]dlord shall have, and hereby reserves and 
excepts, and [NAME_REDACTED] hereby grants a nd assigns to [NAME_REDACTED]dlord, all rights to recover for damages to the 
[NAME_REDACTED]ses and the leasehold interest hereby created, and to compensation accrued or hereafter to 
accrue by reason of such taking or damage.
highlights.explanation: This clause could deprive the tenant of compensation they are legally entitled to.

highlights.category: Indemnification could extend beyond what is legally permissible. Landlords cannot be indemnified for their own negligence under Massachusetts law.
highlights.text:
To the extent 
permitted by law, [NAME_REDACTED] shall indemnify [NAME_REDACTED] dlord against all payments which [NAME_REDACTED]dlord may incur by 
reason of such termination during the residue of the Term.
highlights.explanation: The clause stating the tenant will indemnify the landlord for payments incurred due to termination 'to the extent permitted by law' is risky because it's vague. It suggests indemnification could be required even when illegal. If the termination is a result of the Landlord's fault, indemnification is illegal under Massachusetts law

highlights.category: The landlord retains responsibility for essential building systems and structural elements, and for snow removal, which protects the tenant from potentially costly repairs and ensures safety.
highlights.text: 6.2 [NAME_REDACTED]dlord’s Responsibility.  [NAME_REDACTED]dlord shall be responsible for the electrical wiring and lighting, all plumbing and utility lines serving the [NAME_REDACTED]ses, the heating and ventilating system and the fire protection equipment and syste ms serving the Building, the roof, exterior walls and foundations of the Building, in good and safe order, condition and repair, reasonable wear and tear and damage by fire or other casualty excepted.  [NAME_REDACTED] shall be responsible for removing snow and ice from the [NAME_REDACTED]ses, including all sidewalks, walkways, and parking areas.
highlights.statute: Implied Warranty of Habitability; General landlord-tenant law regarding essential services.
highlights.explanation: The landlord retains responsibility for essential building systems and structural elements, and for snow removal, which protects the tenant from potentially costly repairs and ensures safety.

highlights.category: The Landlord gives 24 hours notice and is not to interfere unreasonably with tenant's use of the premise, which is beneficial to the tenant.
highlights.text: 6.3 Inspection.  Without limiting [NAME_REDACTED]dlord’s rights to access the [NAME_REDACTED]ses under other provisions of this [NAME_REDACTED]se, [NAME_REDACTED]dlord hereby specifically reserves the right to conduct an annua l inspection of the [NAME_REDACTED]ses, and [NAME_REDACTED] shall allow entry and access to [ORG_REDACTED], [ORG_REDACTED], and such other persons as [ORG_REDACTED] may designate, for the purpose of investigating the condition of the of the [NAME_REDACTED]s es.  [NAME_REDACTED]dlord shall provide [NAME_REDACTED] with a minimum notice of twenty -four (24) hours, and not interfere unreasonably with [NAME_REDACTED] use of the [NAME_REDACTED]ses.  [NAME_REDACTED]dlord may provide [NAME_REDACTED] with a report of such assessments and list of repairs or maintenance that [NAME_REDACTED] dlord reasonably determines need to be made.
highlights.explanation: The Landlord gives 24 hours notice and is not to interfere unreasonably with tenant's use of the premise, which is beneficial to the tenant.

highlights.category: The landlord's consent to signage cannot be 'unreasonably withheld'
highlights.text:
8.1 Permitted Uses.  [NAME_REDACTED] shall use the [NAME_REDACTED]ses solely for [ORG_REDACTED]. [NAME_REDACTED] shall keep 
the [NAME_REDACTED]ses in good order, reasonable wear and tear and damage by fire or other casualty only 
excepted, and shall not commit or permit [NAME_REDACTED]'s servants, agents or invitees to commit waste to the 
[NAME_REDACTED]ses.  [NAME_REDACTED] agrees not to erect any  signs on the [NAME_REDACTED]ses, including the exterior of the Building, 
without the prior written consent of the [NAME_REDACTED]dlord, which consent shall not be unreasonably withheld.
highlights.explanation: The landlord's consent to signage cannot be 'unreasonably withheld'

highlights.category: The landlord agrees not to unreasonably withhold approval of the tenant's insurance company.
highlights.text:
10.3.  [ORG_REDACTED].  [NAME_REDACTED]dlord shall be named as an additional insured on all 
insurance policies.  All required insurance shall be written with such companies qualified to do business 
in Massachusetts, as [NAME_REDACTED] shall select and [NAME_REDACTED]dlord shall approve, which  approval [NAME_REDACTED]dlord agrees not 
to withhold unreasonably.
highlights.statute: This can prevent the landlord from forcing the tenant to use a specific, potentially more expensive, insurance company.
highlights.explanation: The landlord agrees not to unreasonably withhold approval of the tenant's insurance company.

highlights.category: Guarantees the tenant's right to quiet enjoyment of the property
highlights.text:
13.2.  [NAME_REDACTED].  [NAME_REDACTED]dlord hereby warrants and covenants that [NAME_REDACTED] shall have peaceful and 
quiet use and possession of the [NAME_REDACTED]ses without hindrance or interruption on the part  of [NAME_REDACTED]dlord, or 
by any other person(s) for whose actions [NAME_REDACTED]dlord is legally responsible, or by any person claiming by, 
through or under [NAME_REDACTED]dlord, except as herein provided.
highlights.statute: Implied Covenant of Quiet Enjoyment, generally recognized under MA law
highlights.explanation: Guarantees the tenant's right to quiet enjoyment of the property

highlights.category: Limits the landlord's right to enter the premises to reasonable times, with notice, except in emergencies. Providing a right of notice before entry protects tenant's privacy and business operations.
highlights.text:
13.3.  [NAME_REDACTED]dlord’s Entry.  [NAME_REDACTED]dlord or its agents may, at reasonable times and wit hout interfering with 
[NAME_REDACTED]'s business operations, enter the [NAME_REDACTED]ses from time to time to make repairs or to inspect the 
[NAME_REDACTED]ses.  [NAME_REDACTED]dlord shall give [NAME_REDACTED] a minimum of twenty -four (24) hours’ notice for such visits, 
provided however that [NAME_REDACTED]dlord may  enter the [NAME_REDACTED]ses at any hour and without prior notice in the 
case of an emergency affecting the [NAME_REDACTED]ses.
highlights.explanation: Limits the landlord's right to enter the premises to reasonable times, with notice, except in emergencies. Providing a right of notice before entry protects tenant's privacy and business operations.
